 I could help you more if you told me what the mock trial's for. Is this a civil or criminal case, and is it a constitution-based argument in front of a panel like the Supreme Court or is it a jury-level performance? It also depends what the rules are, because the mock trials I'm familiar with don't allow the inclusion of outside sources.

 Well, the mock trial's over now... The defense (the side I'm on) lost to a unanimous vote. Some of the jury members said that we were "to full of ourselves". What really gets me is that all 10 of the jurors voted for the prosecution, which is kind of fishy, considering that both of our arguments were pretty even. I have a feeling that bribery was a play in the jurors' verdict. 
 
 What do you think?

Well, the mock trial's over now... The defense (the side I'm on) lost to a unanimous vote. Some of the jury members said that we were "to full of ourselves". What really gets me is that all 10 of the jurors voted for the prosecution, which is kind of fishy, considering that both of our arguments were pretty even. I have a feeling that bribery was a play in the jurors' verdict.

 
 I wouldn't know. High School mock trial through the Bar Association is never won via a jury--the judges simply grade the performance of each individual and tally the score at the end.

I wouldn't know. High School mock trial through the Bar Association is never won via a jury--the judges simply grade the performance of each individual and tally the score at the end.

 
 This is a middle school mock trial. It was a 7th grade Social Studies project, it took about a week or so to complete.

 That would suck. My team got second in the state of Minnesota last year, and so naturally it was a depressing experience being worshipped like a god in my law and order class when we had a mock trial like that. I admit that it was cheap to give my opposing team the rules of evidence on the day of the trial, but I could have made it all up the same.
